items.title: Looking to 'Buy Canadian' at the grocery store? Beware of maple-washing: CBC’s Marketplace Cheat Sheet
items.summary_auto: The CBC's Marketplace rounds up the consumer and health news you need from the week.

items.title: Alcaraz, 22, beats Djokovic to win Australian Open, becoming youngest man to complete career Grand Slam
items.summary_auto: Carlos Alcaraz is the youngest man ever to complete a career Grand Slam after securing the Australian Open title against Novak Djokovic, who had never lost in his 10 previous finals at Melbourne Park.

items.title: FDA warns ‘Dr. Goodenowe’ health centre founder that his recent supplement study put patient health at risk
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has rebuked the founder of Moose Jaw’s controversial Dr. Goodenowe Restorative Health Center, alleging that a recent clinical trial of his supplements put the safety and welfare of research subjects at risk.

items.title: Nova Scotia's credit rating downgraded amid deficit concerns
items.summary_auto: The Nova Scotia government’s credit rating was downgraded by S&P Global this week in response to concerns including the province’s mounting deficit, which Premier Tim Houston recently said could top $1.4 billion.

items.title: New fund addressing intimate partner violence honours Cape Breton woman killed last year
items.summary_auto: The Elizabeth Fry Society's new fund to provide greater education on intimate partner violence is dedicated to a Cape Breton woman who was killed last November.

items.title: Despite the lack of groundhogs, N.L. has its own Feb. 2 traditions
items.summary_auto: Monday morning at sunrise, Punxsutawney Phil will emerge from his burrow and, if he sees his shadow, North America is supposedly in for six more weeks of winter.

items.title: Fact-checking Trump's claims about his 1st year back in the White House
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump likes to throw out a lot of figures during speeches to his base that he says prove how successful his first year back in office has been. But given Trump's proclivity for spreading misinformation, we wanted to see how many of these figures are accurate and backed up by real data.

items.title: Her cousins were killed during deadly Iranian protests. She wants people to know who they were
items.summary_auto: Iranian-Canadian Tayebeh Poshtareh found out from an Instagram post that her cousins had died in the streets of Tehran this month during deadly protests that prompted a bloody crackdown and an internet blackout. She and other Iranians in Canada say the lack of communication is taking a toll on families, while those still in Iran are facing pressure from the regime.

items.title: How a Canadian in Rome is building a Catholic AI from Vatican archives
items.summary_auto: A Canadian entrepreneur in Rome is building Magisterium AI, a Catholic platform trained on church documents and Vatican-linked collections. The project aims to make doctrine searchable at scale, while raising questions about accuracy, authority and how it will be used.

items.title: Former campaign manager says Conservatives should link U.S. relations to cost of living
items.summary_auto: Former Conservative campaign manager Jenni Byrne says her party's messaging on the relationship between Canada and the United States is evolving, and should continue evolving as the situation shifts.

items.title: The Conservative Party is overhauling its policy playbook. Here's what's changing
items.summary_auto: Delegates at the Conservative Party's national convention in Calgary voted overwhelmingly Saturday to enact a "stand your ground"-style law to allow someone to protect themselves with lethal force against an intruder in their home. This was one of dozens of policies debated and adopted by delegates, many of which focused on crime, immigration and social policy.

items.title: Pierre Polievre wants a Churchill base, but experts debate northern Manitoba town's military capacity
items.summary_auto: Party leader Pierre Poilievre says a Conservative government would build a base in Churchill to strengthen Canada's defence systems — but experts argue the northern Manitoba town presents challenges as a military location.

items.title: Evacuation orders remain in Badger, N.L., water levels 'still high'
items.summary_auto: The mayor of Badger says he’s “cautiously optimistic” after seeing a drop in water levels – but river water is still high and evacuation orders remain in place.

items.title: On home turf, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith jabs familiar foes to warm reception
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith flexed her star power amongst Conservative Party faithful on Saturday, advocating for popular conservative policies while not directly addressing the separatist issue that has made headlines this week.

items.title: Judge orders U.S. to free 5-year-old boy, father detained by ICE in Minnesota
items.summary_auto: Images of Liam Conejo Ramos wearing a bunny hat and Spiderman backpack while surrounded by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers sparked even more outcry about the Trump administration's immigration crackdown in Minnesota.

items.title: School bus driver fired after students abandoned in Ottawa parking lot
items.summary_auto: More than three dozen students from Collège catholique Samuel-Genest were left stranded in a parking lot Friday by their school bus driver, according to the local school bus consortium.
